! Funerals s--At the death Of Bulhin or Chlze-
rot, the relations meet together and make loud la

These cuIoues continue till four of the relatives


take the coffin their shoulders, and the rest OF the

finished, a number of women, clad in white. with
wild and dsordercd looks, make the air ring with
thcr lamentations, and appear to be ready to cast
themselves into the grave. The whole ceremony
Indeed, is truly affecting remarkable instance


Of this kind occurred at the funeral of a woman,


whose daughter only seventeen Yeas OF age, tol-
lowed her parent to her long. long home. we
would. says Nj. Ribond, give these expressions OF

4 this grefstruck girl. ssOh, my mother, where are


you going? ! shall see you no more The earth
lis about to you-my cries will not recall you


to lfe-I will stay here. on this grave. The shad-
ow which covers you is about to seize me-my tears
shall make a pah-My mother--my mother,


answer me y Here her voice failed her, and the

were, ..like Nobe all tears"


Not long since. it was the custom to place some


of the furniture of the deceased on the coffin, and


to bury it in thegrave with the body but the clergy

The funerals are aways closed by feast for thu

hands: respectfully submit to their fellow citizens
the following resolutions, which they offer as con-
tanning the unaIterabe principles which animate
them and which they trust to see adopted as the ex-
preston of the sincere opinion Of the State oil Lou.
isana.


RESOLUTIONS.


Resolved, That the writ Of Habeas Corpus, and
trial by jury essentially titute the palladium OF
our liberties that they the two main pill ars ON
which rest the social edifice that to wrest them
from our citizens, is an attack upon the rights of
man. and the sovereignty of the people; and that he
would yainly seek the surages of any true lover OF
their country, who could render himself guilty Of
such an usurpation of power.


Resolved, That we have an entire confidence in the
talents. the zeal, the purity of principles and the
patriosm of the members of our cabinet and that
We found the farcst hopes on all measures emanang
from such an administration.


i Resolved. that wc denounce as calumnious. all
the accusations made against our present secretary
of state, Henry Clay: that we recognize in him the
virtuous citizen, the tried republican. the dstin-
guished orator. the profound dipoma'ist, the ire
proachable public functionary; and that by all these


titles. he is worthy Of the respect, Of the gratitude
and the admiration Of the American people
4 Resolved, That the determination openly avowet
by its enemies to put down the Administrations how
ever pure it be, is outrage against the constituted
authorities of the nation, against the principles O
our government, against the majesty Of the people
an outrage which should excite the Indignation o
every honest citizen, and Of every lover of order.
t Whereupon, the delegates present were success
lively Called and the following signatures affixed b,
them to the said address and resolutions:-
! Tho. Urquhart, g. b. Mllligan, &C. &c. &c.

Seventy petitions were presented and many mo-
tions made too numerous 10 specification.

Were all our columns devoted to the publication
of the proceedings Of Administrator eengs, cau-
ed by the course pursued by the Opposition, they
would scarcely be sufficient for the purpose. 10
day, we select those of the Convention in Louis
lana, not because they are, in all respects, more
worthy Of notice than many others but because
they indicate the opinions and feelings Of men v-
ing at and near the scene OF General Jackson's
greatest glory-and whcre--if at any place-he
established his claims and fitness for the first civil
office in the world Let the reader remember--
that these men, generally, were well acquainted
with Jackson's conduct in Louisiana, and estimate
him not simply from well authenticated tacts--bu'
from actual observation.


Among the Delegates to the Conv ention, we no.
iice, with much pleasure, G. B. Milligan Esq. late
citizen of Maryland, and occasionally residen:
in this Borough-but whu is now, and has been TO-
some years citizen Of Louisiana. 1t is to this gen
tleman, if we mistake not, to whom reference u
made in the reply to the 9Th accusation.

There was meeting of the Agriculturalists,

agement and protection of American Industry. at

preprcy of memorializing Congress in favor of fur
her protection to the growers and manufacturers oi
wool and other domestic productions. Resolutions

1iiarriagc. Formerly, wife, or husband was
never chosen out of their village and this rule is.
indeed, seldom departed from at the present time.
Not long since, a young girl of IIuchsv was about
to be married, contrary their custom, to rich in
habitant of neighbourins village. who persuaded
her to throw off her Chzcrote costume and put on
the dress Of Macon. consisting of rich stus, bright
and gttering With gold embroldcry.-'Th mother
Of the glr being informed Of this change, becomes
indignant seeks her child. and loads her with re-
proaches--the full force of which in their pofois. il
is net easy to transfer into any other language. The
following is the substance:


Unnatural child. behold these fields where we
have endured the burning sun OF harvest What
trouble have not taken to noursh and rear thee.
to set an example, and TO nstil into thee the love
of labor. Thou abandonest our custom"-thou will
soon lose thy virtue Must thou leave thy father
to die in peace? What will he say? What will
our ancestors say? o! may they rise from their
graves to see thee and to punish thee Thou des
plses US, migrate l will no longer acknowledge
4 thee for nv child"


The young woman, with her eyescast upon the
ground, tor time was silent soon, however, her
tears begin to flow--shc hastily tears off her new
dress, and puts on the Chizerote costume
throws the other into the fire. and embraces her mo-
! ther.


| But to return to their marriage ceremonies The
young girl. c'a'lm black, with sash of the same
color, and several gold chains round her neck, leaves
her father, house in triumph to the sound of cheoncs
or ba9ppcs She is followed by great number Of
relations and friends the young men shouting and
hallnon9 forjnv-screaming out their huchcncnS, as
they are called i'll the country pf Bresse.


When they arrive at the church. there is a dispute
between the bride and bridegroom. who shall ente,
first, The GIRLS take the man. and the yDunp apn
; the woman each makes one step forwards, ant
two backwards. and they amu-e themselves III this
way till the time or the performance of the ctremo
: ny arrives.


After the nupial bcnediction. and on leaving th'
church. the wife thus addressed her husband
5 WHY did YOU come 70 seek for me ? She saws il
a loud vulce was very happy why did you no


let me be with my mother = and other questions o
e the like nature.


t At the door Of the church, the new married cou
t pie begin TO dance the whole company follow thei
o example, d. dividing themselves into two bands
one Of men and the other of women, the latter i'm
: media ely proceed with the bride to the house Of he
mother, to partake of the entertainment provided 70


the women and girls who attend the wedding Will
the men with the bridegroom 90 to dine at his faith
d er's house. This double ecnertanment-ths spec
. dy divorce of man and wlc-and this separation
y the sexes, is very remarkable.


e The two enter ltalnments being concluded. mex
the departure that is, the bride quits he


pa'crnal home. The husband, accompanied by a
+. his male relations and friends, presents himself
t. the hahtaton of his 'bctter ha for the purpose
Il conducting her to her future residence Atihe al
A. proach Of the company she melts into tears, utter


the most piercing cries, and bids passionate fart
At we'll to her family. her friends, the servants. til
i cattle. and the fowls particularly the oxen in II
d plough which she calls by their names. She the
ID takes leave Of the furniture and other inanimate
$. and lastly bids 'good by' to the house in whit
she has passed SO long and so happy portion ofh
L life.


y She tears herself from the place, and at last re


cles the house of her husbands father Here Il
Al dancers are busy with their .'many twinkling fee
the Iesta board is spread, and sumptuous su
ne pcr is prepared for the guests sand when the mig
draws on. and the festivities are about to termina
n the bride again sheds tears becomes timd and CO
u fused and, ..hall-consentng half-relenting,''
i signs herself to the arms of her husband. s.Ne
'r add says NJ. Ribond. that the more hashl
nd the lady is, the viruons she is esteemed ~

POPULAR CUSTOMS, SC. IN FRANCE.


The .9in.

United States and upon our own. !
He has violated the sacred right to the writ OF t
habcas corpus.
lie has caused to be arrested and imprisoned, !
firm and courageous Judge. who, mindful OF his oath
en,eavored to cause tn be respected individual llb-
erty and to maintain the supremacy ot the law.
lie has insulted this state the person OF her chiel
magistrate. William e. G. Claiborne, in this VIC
tim to his devotion to the public good, and to his
love Of country for. induced by these sentiments
he had transferred to him all his military authority,
and put at his disposal all the resources OF the state
He has. in direct violation of the orders whichhe
had received from his government, committed acts
of hostility against neutral nation, and possessed
himself of a portion of her soil acts the more res
ponsible as they exposed the republic to all the hor
rors Of war; if the injured nation had not been N
such state of feebleness that she could not demand
satisfaction for such an injury. 4
He has denounced US in mass he has denounced
many of our most respectable citizens, and Our own
legislature, as traitors % the country although at
that time and ever since, we have all given prons
of our patriotism. our devotion TO the public good, 7
and our sincere attachment 10 the Union
But, saw his partisans, his arbitrary acts upon the
soil of Louisiana, were required by necessity: the
enemy were upon our territory or in our waters
their presence placed in imminent hazard this por-
ton of the Union. Vain excuse The defeated
enemy had for several weeks before retired from
our soil, and had embarked in their vessels. Is 1t
not absurd to suppose that, vanqushea as the% were
they would again trust their fortunes to the tate OF
arms , And BESIDES was it danger Of his situation
or the case of necessity which caused him to exer-
else those arbitrary and tyranncal acts OF which
he was guilty at Pensacola. towards Gov Caava,
an officer invested with public character, and who
was only accountable to the king of Spain Tor his
conduct? Was it necessity, or the enemy winch
dictated the arbitrary measures pursued by \. jack
son against Judge Fromentln?


Is it, in fine, the law of necessity. which ten
wears after the has induced the general to de-
fame this state, in the persons of its legislators


Nav the people of Louisiana never permit the
past to be efaced from their memory. May they
pro6tng by these terrible lessons, consider their
present condition, the happiness, the liberty. the
prosperity they enjoy and with them it is lett. to
pronounce if it be reasonable to hope. that they
should preserve for any time, the advantages they
possess under the sage and paternai administration
of John Quincy Adams. if they cause him to descend
from that situation, to which he has been constitu-
tionally called, by the representatives OF the people
and the plurality Of surages, and replace him by
man. who, as his friends confess. has neither the ac-
qurements. nor the talents. nor the application, re-
quired in the first magistrate OF the Union


Resolved. That we consider the American Fedc-
ration as one and ndivlslbe; that, as has been
taught us BY the hero of our independence. we deem
that the interests of each part OF the republic form
the interests of the whGle; 1ha therefore, in tht
choice which we have to make of the first magistrate
of the state we repe the idea that we ought to b.
influenced by local distinctions and we pride our
selves in proclaimng TO the world, that it is only Il
the most capable. the most vrtuous. that we vii
give our preference. which ever be the section of bt
Union to which he belongs.


RescIued, That upon these considerations. WI
will promute. to the best of ability. the reelec
tion of JOHN QUINCY ADAMS 10 the presiden
cy and that, among other reass switch dccrnln
us, we delight to enumerate the following =


st. Because, young, he was distinguished b
Washington at later period. he was honoured b
the confidence of Jefferson. Madison aud Monroe
and that, brought up in their school. be has shown
since his coming to the presidency, that he has we
studied their lessons, and that he was worthy to b
the successor of these fathers of their country.


2d. Because our institutions. and the care of h;
social part which unltes the American family, car
not be confined to purer hands, than to those of tn
man, Who in every duty which he has been cae
upon to perform, has always shown himself i
most firm supporter, and Its most eloquent defer
der


Cd. Because, long before he was called to Il
head of affairs, the talents. the patriotism, and Il
integrity displayed in the exercise of the enne
functions. with which he bad been charged, gave
the American people sure pledge OF his condu
as chief of the nation. and that the opinion ente
tanned of him has been fully justified by all the &C
of his administration.


4th. Because the republic, which. by the wislo
of his predecessors in the presidency had been tt
for the highest desnies, has ceased to b
under the influence ofhis genius happy within. re
pccted without and that, still shielded by the SAL!
every thing presages to him further prosperous al
brilliant career.


5. Because his rcpublicanism and his love Of
der are too we'll known, to allow us to fear ht
during his presidency. the military authority W
ever dare to encroach upon the civil, and thus G
danror thn safe nf tho state

Were all our columns devoted to the publication
of the proceedings Of Administrator eengs, cau-
ed by the course pursued by the Opposition, they
would scarcely be sufficient for the purpose. 10
day, we select those of the Convention in Louis
lana, not because they are, in all respects, more
worthy Of notice than many others but because
they indicate the opinions and feelings Of men v-
ing at and near the scene OF General Jackson's
greatest glory-and whcre--if at any place-he
established his claims and fitness for the first civil
office in the world Let the reader remember--
that these men, generally, were well acquainted
with Jackson's conduct in Louisiana, and estimate
him not simply from well authenticated tacts--bu'
from actual observation.


Among the Delegates to the Conv ention, we no.
iice, with much pleasure, G. B. Milligan Esq. late
citizen of Maryland, and occasionally residen:
in this Borough-but whu is now, and has been TO-
some years citizen Of Louisiana. 1t is to this gen
tleman, if we mistake not, to whom reference u
made in the reply to the 9Th accusation.

full articles.headline: CONGkESSAOSAA.
full articles.article:
MIR. Benton gave notice that on Monday he
should introduce bill for the reduction OF the u
s. Military Peace Establishment.


The Senate proceeded to the election OF Its DILL
GERS for the present Congress, when the following
were declared to be elected, and took
the oahs OF their respective offices


Walter Lowrle. Secretary


Mountjoy Bayly, Sergeant at Arms and Door
keeper


Henry Tins, Assistant Doorkeeper.


This being the day appointed for the election OF
the Standing Committees, the Senate proceeded to
ballot for the Chairman and members OF each in ro-
tation, when the following appointments were made !:


Committee Of Foreign keatons.-Mr. Macon,
Chairman Messrs. Sandford, Bell, Tazewe!, and
White.


Committee on Finance. Mr.. Smith. of Md.
Chairman Messrs. Nc. Lane, Smith, Of S. c. Par
is and Branch.


Committee on Commerce. Mr.. Woodbury.,
Chairman Mcssrs. Silsbee Me. Lane, Johnson,
La aud Williams.


Committee ON Manufactures. Dickerson,
Chairman Messrs. Knight, Ridgely, Ruggles, and
Barard.


Committee on Agriculture. Mr.. Branch, Chair
man Messrs. Bateman, Wiley, Bogny, and Bar
nard.


Committee on Military Afiairs.-Mr. Harrison,
Chairman Messrs. johnson, of Ky. Chandler, Bar
ton, and Hendricks


Commttee on the Militia. MIR. Chandler, Chair
man Messrs. HARRISON, Mckinley, Marks, ant
Tyler.


Committee on Naval Alfars-Alr. Hayne. Chair
mau Messrs Robbins, Tazewell, Seymor, ant
Woodbury..
The Senate then adjourned.

full articles.headline: "AMERICAN SYS'rEMn
full articles.article:
There was meeting of the Agriculturalists,
Manufacturers and others, friendly to the encour-
agement and protection of American Industry. at
Albany, Nov. 26th to take into consideration the
preprcy of memorializing Congress in favor of fur
her protection to the growers and manufacturers oi
wool and other domestic productions. Resolutions

full articles.headline:
POPULAR CUSTOMS, SC. IN FRANCE.


The .9in.
full articles.article:
The lin.


1iiarriagc. Formerly, wife, or husband was
never chosen out of their village and this rule is.
indeed, seldom departed from at the present time.
Not long since, a young girl of IIuchsv was about
to be married, contrary their custom, to rich in
habitant of neighbourins village. who persuaded
her to throw off her Chzcrote costume and put on
the dress Of Macon. consisting of rich stus, bright
and gttering With gold embroldcry.-'Th mother
Of the glr being informed Of this change, becomes
indignant seeks her child. and loads her with re-
proaches--the full force of which in their pofois. il
is net easy to transfer into any other language. The
following is the substance:


Unnatural child. behold these fields where we
have endured the burning sun OF harvest What
trouble have not taken to noursh and rear thee.
to set an example, and TO nstil into thee the love
of labor. Thou abandonest our custom"-thou will
soon lose thy virtue Must thou leave thy father
to die in peace? What will he say? What will
our ancestors say? o! may they rise from their
graves to see thee and to punish thee Thou des
plses US, migrate l will no longer acknowledge
4 thee for nv child"


The young woman, with her eyescast upon the
ground, tor time was silent soon, however, her
tears begin to flow--shc hastily tears off her new
dress, and puts on the Chizerote costume
throws the other into the fire. and embraces her mo-
! ther.


| But to return to their marriage ceremonies The
young girl. c'a'lm black, with sash of the same
color, and several gold chains round her neck, leaves
her father, house in triumph to the sound of cheoncs
or ba9ppcs She is followed by great number Of
relations and friends the young men shouting and
hallnon9 forjnv-screaming out their huchcncnS, as
they are called i'll the country pf Bresse.


When they arrive at the church. there is a dispute
between the bride and bridegroom. who shall ente,
first, The GIRLS take the man. and the yDunp apn
; the woman each makes one step forwards, ant
two backwards. and they amu-e themselves III this
way till the time or the performance of the ctremo
: ny arrives.


After the nupial bcnediction. and on leaving th'
church. the wife thus addressed her husband
5 WHY did YOU come 70 seek for me ? She saws il
a loud vulce was very happy why did you no


let me be with my mother = and other questions o
e the like nature.


t At the door Of the church, the new married cou
t pie begin TO dance the whole company follow thei
o example, d. dividing themselves into two bands
one Of men and the other of women, the latter i'm
: media ely proceed with the bride to the house Of he
mother, to partake of the entertainment provided 70


the women and girls who attend the wedding Will
the men with the bridegroom 90 to dine at his faith
d er's house. This double ecnertanment-ths spec
. dy divorce of man and wlc-and this separation
y the sexes, is very remarkable.


e The two enter ltalnments being concluded. mex
the departure that is, the bride quits he


pa'crnal home. The husband, accompanied by a
+. his male relations and friends, presents himself
t. the hahtaton of his 'bctter ha for the purpose
Il conducting her to her future residence Atihe al
A. proach Of the company she melts into tears, utter


the most piercing cries, and bids passionate fart
At we'll to her family. her friends, the servants. til
i cattle. and the fowls particularly the oxen in II
d plough which she calls by their names. She the
ID takes leave Of the furniture and other inanimate
$. and lastly bids 'good by' to the house in whit
she has passed SO long and so happy portion ofh
L life.


y She tears herself from the place, and at last re


cles the house of her husbands father Here Il
Al dancers are busy with their .'many twinkling fee
the Iesta board is spread, and sumptuous su
ne pcr is prepared for the guests sand when the mig
draws on. and the festivities are about to termina
n the bride again sheds tears becomes timd and CO
u fused and, ..hall-consentng half-relenting,''
i signs herself to the arms of her husband. s.Ne
'r add says NJ. Ribond. that the more hashl
nd the lady is, the viruons she is esteemed ~
NJ In the other parts of la Bresse, the marriages
mt equally accompanied by some very singular custom

United States and upon our own. !
He has violated the sacred right to the writ OF t
habcas corpus.
lie has caused to be arrested and imprisoned, !
firm and courageous Judge. who, mindful OF his oath
en,eavored to cause tn be respected individual llb-
erty and to maintain the supremacy ot the law.
lie has insulted this state the person OF her chiel
magistrate. William e. G. Claiborne, in this VIC
tim to his devotion to the public good, and to his
love Of country for. induced by these sentiments
he had transferred to him all his military authority,
and put at his disposal all the resources OF the state
He has. in direct violation of the orders whichhe
had received from his government, committed acts
of hostility against neutral nation, and possessed
himself of a portion of her soil acts the more res
ponsible as they exposed the republic to all the hor
rors Of war; if the injured nation had not been N
such state of feebleness that she could not demand
satisfaction for such an injury. 4
He has denounced US in mass he has denounced
many of our most respectable citizens, and Our own
legislature, as traitors % the country although at
that time and ever since, we have all given prons
of our patriotism. our devotion TO the public good, 7
and our sincere attachment 10 the Union
But, saw his partisans, his arbitrary acts upon the
soil of Louisiana, were required by necessity: the
enemy were upon our territory or in our waters
their presence placed in imminent hazard this por-
ton of the Union. Vain excuse The defeated
enemy had for several weeks before retired from
our soil, and had embarked in their vessels. Is 1t
not absurd to suppose that, vanqushea as the% were
they would again trust their fortunes to the tate OF
arms , And BESIDES was it danger Of his situation
or the case of necessity which caused him to exer-
else those arbitrary and tyranncal acts OF which
he was guilty at Pensacola. towards Gov Caava,
an officer invested with public character, and who
was only accountable to the king of Spain Tor his
conduct? Was it necessity, or the enemy winch
dictated the arbitrary measures pursued by \. jack
son against Judge Fromentln?


Is it, in fine, the law of necessity. which ten
wears after the has induced the general to de-
fame this state, in the persons of its legislators


Nav the people of Louisiana never permit the
past to be efaced from their memory. May they
pro6tng by these terrible lessons, consider their
present condition, the happiness, the liberty. the
prosperity they enjoy and with them it is lett. to
pronounce if it be reasonable to hope. that they
should preserve for any time, the advantages they
possess under the sage and paternai administration
of John Quincy Adams. if they cause him to descend
from that situation, to which he has been constitu-
tionally called, by the representatives OF the people
and the plurality Of surages, and replace him by
man. who, as his friends confess. has neither the ac-
qurements. nor the talents. nor the application, re-
quired in the first magistrate OF the Union


Resolved. That we consider the American Fedc-
ration as one and ndivlslbe; that, as has been
taught us BY the hero of our independence. we deem
that the interests of each part OF the republic form
the interests of the whGle; 1ha therefore, in tht
choice which we have to make of the first magistrate
of the state we repe the idea that we ought to b.
influenced by local distinctions and we pride our
selves in proclaimng TO the world, that it is only Il
the most capable. the most vrtuous. that we vii
give our preference. which ever be the section of bt
Union to which he belongs.


RescIued, That upon these considerations. WI
will promute. to the best of ability. the reelec
tion of JOHN QUINCY ADAMS 10 the presiden
cy and that, among other reass switch dccrnln
us, we delight to enumerate the following =


st. Because, young, he was distinguished b
Washington at later period. he was honoured b
the confidence of Jefferson. Madison aud Monroe
and that, brought up in their school. be has shown
since his coming to the presidency, that he has we
studied their lessons, and that he was worthy to b
the successor of these fathers of their country.


2d. Because our institutions. and the care of h;
social part which unltes the American family, car
not be confined to purer hands, than to those of tn
man, Who in every duty which he has been cae
upon to perform, has always shown himself i
most firm supporter, and Its most eloquent defer
der


Cd. Because, long before he was called to Il
head of affairs, the talents. the patriotism, and Il
integrity displayed in the exercise of the enne
functions. with which he bad been charged, gave
the American people sure pledge OF his condu
as chief of the nation. and that the opinion ente
tanned of him has been fully justified by all the &C
of his administration.


4th. Because the republic, which. by the wislo
of his predecessors in the presidency had been tt
for the highest desnies, has ceased to b
under the influence ofhis genius happy within. re
pccted without and that, still shielded by the SAL!
every thing presages to him further prosperous al
brilliant career.


5. Because his rcpublicanism and his love Of
der are too we'll known, to allow us to fear ht
during his presidency. the military authority W
ever dare to encroach upon the civil, and thus G
danror thn safe nf tho state
